items.title: Sophie Kinsella, author behind Confessions of a Shopaholic books, dies at 55
items.summary_auto: Sophie Kinsella was first diagnosed with an aggressive form of brain cancer in 2022, and revealed the diagnosis in 2024. In a social media post announcing her death, the author’s family said she “took nothing for granted” and battled her illness with courage.

items.title: Alberta Legislature passes bill invoking Charter override for 4th time
items.summary_auto: Alberta's governing United Conservatives stayed up into the early pre-dawn hours of Wednesday morning to pass a bill that marks the fourth time in under two months they have used the Charter's notwithstanding clause.

items.title: Prince George, B.C., conservation group fixes deadly problem for Nechako River fish
items.summary_auto: The Spruce City Wildlife Association has reconnected a side channel at Cottonwood Island Park to the Nechako River, restoring a critical fish habitat and preventing fish from being trapped and left to die during periods of low water.

items.title: Ukraine's Zelenskyy 'ready for elections' after Trump suggests Kyiv is 'using war' to avoid them
items.summary_auto: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said Tuesday he was prepared to hold elections within three months if the U.S. and other Kyiv allies could ensure the security of the vote.

items.title: Home is where the swag is: Sask. music fan amasses souvenirs from 1,200 shows
items.summary_auto: Visitors to Roque Andres, Jr.'s house in Saskatoon immediately notice a collection of mementos from decades of attending rock concerts.

items.title: 13 years later, the IKEA monkey is all grown up — and his sanctuary is at capacity
items.summary_auto: Thirteen years after an attempted escape from an IKEA parking lot, Darwin the monkey has been living out his life at Storybook Primate Sanctuary, the only one of its kind in Canada. He may be shy, but volunteers say he is thriving.

items.title: N.S. fishermen concerned sewer outfall will affect harbour livelihoods
items.summary_auto: A pipe expected to carry treated sewage into the south harbour in Ingonish, N.S., has fishermen concerned about the possible impact on fishing in general and their lobster storage operations.

items.title: Facing down Parkinson's and dementia, Robert Munsch says he still has 'about 50 stories' in him
items.summary_auto: After a lifetime of writing beloved children’s books, Robert Munsch is now living with dementia and Parkinson’s disease. In an exclusive interview that he calls his "last hurrah," the bestselling author tells CBC News chief correspondent Adrienne Arsenault about the world that shaped his stories, revealing a secret plan to release dozens of books after his death.

items.title: DND scrambles to figure out how to mobilize and equip a citizens' army: documents
items.summary_auto: A series of internal documents shows the Defence Department is struggling to figure out how to equip a citizens' army of up to 300,000 supplemental reservists, while also trying to rebuild its regular and primary reserve forces. A DND presentation obtained by CBC News shows strained supply chains, an absence of warehouses and the possibility of repurposing uniforms are a concern.

items.title: Is Trump’s stark new security strategy the end of the liberal world order? Europeans will need convincing
items.summary_auto: European leaders must decide whether to reject or embrace the conclusions of U.S. President Donald Trump’s new security strategy. It berates and insults them and calls into question some of the key premises of collective security that have helped protect the continent for eight decades.

items.title: Time's almost up to claim a slice of the bread price-fixing settlement. But how safe is your data?
items.summary_auto: Canadians have until Dec. 12 to get their slice of a $500-million settlement in a class-action lawsuit related to the industry-wide price fixing of bread. But some have expressed concern about sharing their personal information online.

items.title: U.S. businesses claim Canada is a back door for products from China
items.summary_auto: As U.S. President Donald Trump sticks with tariffs on imports from Canada, some American industries are accusing Canadian competitors of using cheap materials from China in ways that violate free-trade rules and undercut U.S. companies.

items.title: 'Venezuela will breathe again': María Corina Machado's daughter delivers her Nobel Peace Prize speech
items.summary_auto: María Corina Machado dedicated her Nobel Peace Prize to the political prisoners and human rights activists fighting for democracy in Venezuela in a speech delivered by her daughter at a ceremony in Norway on Wednesday.

items.title: Medication to treat postpartum depression approved by Health Canada
items.summary_auto: Health Canada has approved the first drug designed to treat postpartum depression. The regulator says zuranolone, a pill sold under the brand name Zurzuvae, is authorized in Canada to relieve symptoms of moderate or severe depression after childbirth.

items.title: Toronto is Canada's 'rattiest' city, according to new ranking | Hanomansing Tonight
items.summary_auto: Toronto retains its title as the ‘rattiest’ city in Canada, according to the latest ranking from pest control service Orkin Canada. Kaylee Byers, an assistant professor in the school of population and public health at the University of British Columbia, talks to Hanomansing Tonight about tracking rat populations.

items.title: Liberals back Bloc's proposal to remove religious exemption from hate speech laws
items.summary_auto: Liberal MPs on the House justice committee backed a Bloc Québécois proposal to remove a religious exemption from Canada’s hate speech laws — after the suggestion initially appeared to halt the government's anti-hate legislation.

items.title: No charges laid in crash that killed 4 students and teacher from Walkerton, Ont.: police
items.summary_auto: Seven months after four students and their teacher were killed in a multi-vehicle crash while returning home to Walkerton, Ont. from a high school softball tournament, provincial police have ended their investigation and said no charges will be laid.

items.title: Air Transat, pilots' union reach tentative deal to avert strike, airline's parent company says
items.summary_auto: Air Transat passengers breathed a sigh of relief Tuesday evening after the company reached a tentative deal with its pilot union, narrowly avoiding a strike on the cusp of the busy holiday travel period.

items.title: Cost of Carney's Egypt summit flight ballooned to $736K with no air force plane available
items.summary_auto: Prime Minister Mark Carney’s last-minute trip to a Gaza peace summit in Egypt in October cost Canadian taxpayers over $736,466 — more than three times higher than it would have been if the Royal Canadian Air Force had been able to supply a plane.

items.title: How Canada’s Big 6 banks made a ton of money in 2025 | About That
items.summary_auto: Canada's six largest banks have released their earnings for the 2025 fiscal year, and the results have blown past expectations. Andrew Chang breaks down financial statements from BMO, CIBC, National Bank, RBC, Scotiabank and TD to explain what's driving the gains. Images provided by The Canadian Press, Reuters and Getty Images

items.title: Patients seeking doctors losing faith in Ontario's centralized waitlist
items.summary_auto: Ontario's auditor general found Health Care Connect is failing to match patients with primary care providers. Meanwhile, some clinics are filling their own rosters.

items.title: Trump's threats to tariff Canadian fertilizer imports could hurt Sask. potash industry
items.summary_auto: Donald Trump’s threats to tariff Canadian fertilizer imports could damage Saskatchewan’s potash industry if demand for the mineral critical in making fertilizer drops off, according to a University of Saskatchewan professor.

items.title: Armed kidnappings are keeping thousands of Nigerian children out of school
items.summary_auto: Sending children to school has become too dangerous for many families in Nigeria, where armed kidnappings have become too common.

items.title: N.S. First Nation bans premier, cabinet ministers from band property 'as undesirables'
items.summary_auto: Sipekne’katik First Nation is once again chastising the Houston government and says that the premier and two of his cabinet ministers are not welcome on reserve lands. The premier's office says it takes the message as a threat.

items.title: Sipekne’katik First Nation bans Houston, cabinet ministers in scathing rebuke
items.summary_auto: Sipekne’katik First Nation is once again chastising the Houston government and says that the premier and two of his cabinet ministers are not welcome on reserve lands. The premier's office says it takes the message as a threat.

items.title: Kirsten Hillman, Canada’s longtime ambassador to the U.S., is stepping down
Dylan Cease says decision to join AL champion Blue Jays was 'inevitable'
items.summary_auto: At a news conference on Tuesday, the Blue Jays' newest starting pitcher Dylan Cease spoke about why he signed with Toronto. The right-hander inked a seven-year deal worth $210 million US, the largest free-agent contract in team history.

items.title: Naval member rescued off Vancouver Island after spending more than 2 hours in water
items.summary_auto: Maritime Forces Pacific says the Joint Rescue Co-ordination Centre in Victoria was alerted to the person falling overboard from an inflatable boat at about 2:45 p.m. Monday. They spent two hours in the water before being rescued.

items.title: Family of 18-year-old Niagara, Ont. woman told by cemetery they won't accommodate Muslim burial
items.summary_auto: The family of a young Niagara woman who died in a car accident has been told she won’t be buried in their local cemetery because it won’t accommodate Muslim burial traditions, their imam says.

items.title: What’s happening between Thailand and Cambodia?
items.summary_auto: The latest violence between Thailand and Cambodia is part of a long conflict over territory near their shared border. This week’s clashes threaten a fragile ceasefire that was brokered back in October. CBC’s Salimah Shivji explains how we got here.

items.title: Atmospheric river to bring heavy rain to B.C.'s South Coast, orange warning issued for Fraser Valley
items.summary_auto: An atmospheric river headed for B.C. 's South Coast will bring significant rainfall to parts of the Lower Mainland. It's prompting Environment and Climate Change Canada to issue an orange warning, under its new colour-coded warning system, for parts of the Fraser Valley.

items.title: Australia's social media ban for users under 16 has started, and young users have found workarounds
items.summary_auto: Eyes around the world are turned to Australia as its world-first ban on social media for users under age 16 takes effect. The tough new law aims to block Australian children and younger teens from addictive platforms and harmful content online.

items.title: Australia's social media ban for users under 16 starts now
items.summary_auto: Eyes around the world are turned to Australia as its world-first ban on social media for users under age 16 takes effect. The tough new law aims to block Australian children and younger teens from addictive platforms and harmful content online.
